results.content: So far it is a good match. I had a few problems setting up the project, but those were purely on my end. In my opinion the zoom level is too hiogh, you can see too little of the code. And it is unneccessary to be able to see the lecturer all the time

results.content:
As a Rust beginner with some web-server knowledge this course was an excellent and short introduction to some of the tools in the Rust ecosystem. 

Content is presented in a very direct way, so as the requirements state bring ~some~ Rust knowledge.   This is a great follow-up for when you finish the the Rust book! 

The only downside of the course is that the web-framework, Rocket, seems to be undergoing quite active dev in prep for a 0.5 release. Through no fault of the author, this means some of the code needs a bit of reworking. However, the fixes are relatively simple, are in the Q&A comments, and the author is extremely responsive which helps!

It would be nice to see a more advanced course maybe using postgres + actix (the latter framework seems more stable!)

response.content:
Yes, i hope 0.5 will be released soon, so we don't have anymore breaking changes.
Thank you for identifying some of these changes and even more for providing solutions for them - very helpful for other students i am sure.

I am preparing a course for fully async web servers but with warp and sqlx - hopefully i will be able to release it soon.

Cheers and thank you for the review

results.content:
Straight forward.
The trainer knows how to introduce basics. He explains the stuff we are doing in a simple way.
Perfect for beginning with Rust and rocket.rs
results.content_html:

results.content: Being a beginner in rust programming, I was very happy with the quality of instruction and the material included. The instructor does not waste your time with "filler" videos explaining what he is "going to teach", he gets you right to the topic, and at the end you have a full REST API with a database and know how to create your own. Ive taken many of the rust courses in Udemy and think this was the best. Highly recommend.
results.content_html: Being a beginner in rust programming, I was very happy with the quality of instruction and the material included. The instructor does not waste your time with "filler" videos explaining what he is "going to teach", he gets you right to the topic, and at the end you have a full REST API with a database and know how to create your own. Ive taken many of the rust courses in Udemy and think this was the best. Highly recommend.

results.content: The instructor knew about the subject. His voice was a little uninspired. Even if the Linux service installation part looked rushed, it was helpful. I was a bit surprised with the insert / find combination to find the auto-generated id. This might work with Sqlite (I don't really know), but that would be too little for a real SQL database with parallel requests. It was a good course for an introduction to building web APIs in Rust with Rocket and Diesel. Thank you!

response.content:
Thank you for the review! 
Yes, this problem with retrieving the last inserted id is an sqlite-specific problem. Postgres supports returning the last inserted row if you call get_results() instead of execute(). MySQL i am not sure, i haven't tried yet. See also the insert_into() documentation
https://docs.diesel.rs/diesel/fn.insert_into.html
